A study was conducted to find out whether participation in meditation influences well-being in children.
Hence a group of children who have not participated in meditation before but are now planning to begin
participating in meditation were given a well being scale before they began meditation. The children
were administered the same test again after 2 months of meditation. The well being was measured on an

-- 95 of 202 --

internal scale, with higher scores indicating higher well being. The scores on the scale were normally
distributed. The scores are given below.
Before 	After
4 	6
8 	5
10 	11
12 	10
14 	15
16 	17
18 	16

options.C: Meditation has both positive and negative effect on well being

options.B: Participation in meditation leads to just above the well-being score after meditation

options.D:
Participation in meditation has no significant effect
(96-100)
Lev S. Vygotsky developed a theory of cognitive development. He explained that experienced adults help
children with innate basic capabilities to attain more complex and higher order cognitive capabilities. To
describe and assess this potential, he proposed the notion of ZPD. Based on Vygotskian thinking, an
instructional process was developed in which the more knowledgeable partner adjusts the amount and

-- 96 of 202 --

type of support he offers to fit with the child's learning needs over the course of interaction. According to
Vygotsky, psychological tools and signs facilitate and direct thinking process.

questions.text: The ZPD stands for

The psychological tools and signs such as language, counting, mnemonics, algebric symbols, art and
writing that facilitate and direct thinking process is called by Vygotsky as:
ZPD is defined by Vygotsky as

options.A:
The region of sensitivity for learning characterized by the difference between the developmental
level when the child is working alone and the level he/she is capable of reaching with the aid of
an adult
options.B:
The region of difference between inability to use a known thing and benefit from the use of such
a strategy
options.C:
The region of learning what a child has learnt from experience and knows about the world in
general
options.D:
The region of ability to fit into change and choose environments that best fulfill the child's
needs and desires to learn from society and culture.

questions.text: The theory of Vygotsky is called

options.C: Socio cultural theory of cognitive development
options.D: Bio sociocultural theory of cognitive development

questions.text:
The instructional process in which the more knowledgeable partner adjusts the amount and type of
support he offers to fit with the child's learning needs over the course of interaction is called:
